3.0: to her, and opened her womb.1 The Key of the Revival of the Dead, for it is written, And ye shall
3.1: know that I am the Lord, when I have opened your graves.2 In Palestine they said: Also the Key of
3.2: Sustenance, for it is said, Thou openest thy hand etc.3 Why does not R. Johanan include also this
3.3: [key]? — Because in his view sustenance is [included in] Rain.4
3.4: R. ELIEZER SAYS: ON THE FIRST DAY OF THE FEAST etc. The question was asked,
3.5: Whence did R. Eliezer derive this? Did he learn it from Lulab5 or from the Libation of Water?6 If he
3.6: learnt it from Lulab, then just as the obligation of the use of the Lulab comes into force on the [first]
3.7: day of Tabernacles, so too should we begin to make mention of rain on that day. Or perhaps he learnt
3.8: it from Libation. [If so, then] just as Water Libation may be [carried out] on the evening [preceding
3.9: the first day] — (for a Master [interpreting the verse], And the meal-offering thereof and their
3.10: drink-offerings,7 said, Even by night)-so too should one begin to make mention of rain on that
3.11: evening!8 — Come and hear: R. Abbahu said: R. Eliezer deduced it from Lulab only. Some there are
3.12: who say: R. Abbahu had a tradition. Whilst others say: He based it on a Baraitha. Which is the
3.13: Baraitha? — It has been taught: ‘When do we [begin to] make mention of Rain? R. Eliezer says:
3.14: From the time of the taking up of the Lulab; R. Joshua says, From the time when the Lulab is
3.15: discarded.9 Said R. Eliezer: Seeing that these Four Species are intended only to make intercession
3.16: for water,10 therefore as these cannot [grow] without water so the world [too] cannot exist without
3.17: water. R. Joshua said to him: Is not rain on the Feast a sure sign of [God's] anger? R. Eliezer replied:
3.18: I too did not say to pray but to make mention. And just as one makes mention of the Revival of the
3.19: Dead all the year round11 although it will take place only in its proper time, so too should mention be
3.20: made of the Power of Rain all the year round although it comes only in its due season. Therefore if
3.21: one desires to make mention all the year round he may do so. Rabbi says: I hold the view that when
3.22: one ceases to pray [for rain]12 one should also no longer make mention of it. R. Judah b. Bathyra
3.23: says: On the second day of the Feast one [begins] to make mention. R. Akiba says: On the sixth day
3.24: of the Feast. R. Judah says in the name of R. Joshua: The last to step before the Ark on the last day
3.25: of the Feast makes mention, the first does not; on the first day of Passover the first makes mention,
3.26: the last does not. Did not then R. Eliezer reply well to R. Joshua?- R. Joshua can answer you: It is
3.27: quite in order to make mention of the Revival of the Dead [all the year round], since any day may be
3.28: its time, but is rain seasonable at all times? Have we not learnt: Should Nisan terminate and then rain
3.29: fall it is a sign of [God's] anger, for it is said, Is it not wheat harvest to-day etc.?13
3.30: ‘R. Judah b. Bathyra says: on the second day of the Feast one [begins] to make mention’. What is
3.31: R. Judah b. Bathyra's reason? — It has been taught: R. Judah b. Bathyra says, Of the second day of
3.32: the Feast, Scripture Says, we-niskehem,14 [‘and their drink-offerings’] and of the sixth day,
3.33: u-nesakeah15 [‘and its drink-offerings’] and of the seventh day, kemishpatam16 [according to their
3.34: rule]. Note [the letters] Mem, Yod, Mem which form the word mayim [‘water’].17 Here you have the
3.35: biblical allusion to the Libation of Water. And what makes him [R. Judah b. Bathyra] fix it on the
3.36: second day? — Because [the first of the allusions to the Water Libation] is found in connection [with
3.37: the order for] the second day. Hence why we should [begin] to make mention on the second day. R.
3.38: Akiba says: On the sixth day of the Feast one [begins] to make mention, for of the sixth day
3.39: Scripture says, And its drink-offerings.18 Scripture thus speaks of two libations,19 the Libation of
3.40: Water and the Libation of Wine. Perhaps both Libations must be of wine? — He [R. Akiba] is of the
3.41: same opinion as R. Judah b. Bathyra who said, There is an allusion to water.2

46.5: R. Jose of Yokereth? He replied: Yes. R. Ashi then asked him: Why did you leave him, Sir, and
46.6: come here? He replied: How could the man who showed no mercy to his son and daughter show
46.8: What happened to his son? Once R. Jose had day-labourers [working] in the field; night set in and
46.9: no food was brought to them and they said to his son, ‘We are hungry’. Now they were resting under
46.10: a fig tree and he exclaimed: Fig tree, fig tree, bring forth thy fruit that my father's labourers may eat.
46.11: It brought forth fruit and they ate. Meanwhile the father came and said to them, Do not bear a
46.12: grievance against me; the reason for my delay is because I have been occupied up till now on an
46.13: errand of charity. The labourers replied, May God satisfy you even as your son has satisfied us.
46.14: Whereupon he asked: Whence? And they told him what had happened. Thereupon he said to his son:
46.15: My son, you have troubled your Creator to cause the fig tree to bring forth its fruits before its time,
46.16: may you too be taken hence before your time!
46.17: What happened to his daughter? He had a beautiful daughter. One day he saw a man boring a hole
46.18: in the fence so that he might catch a glimpse of her. He said to the man, What is [the meaning of]
46.19: this? And the man answered: Master, if I am not worthy enough to marry her, may I not at least be
46.20: worthy to catch a glimpse of her? Thereupon he exclaimed: My daughter, you are a source of trouble
46.21: to mankind; return to the dust so that men may not sin because of you. He also had an ass. When it
46.22: was hired out for the day [the people who hired it] would place, in the evening, the hire on its back
46.23: and the ass would make its way home to its master. If, however, the money was too much or too
46.24: little, it would not go. One day a pair of sandals were left on its back and the ass would not move
46.25: until they were removed and only then did it proceed.
46.26: Whenever the collectors of charity caught sight of R. Eleazar b. Birtah2 they would hide
46.27: themselves from him, because he was in the habit of giving away to them all that he had. One day he
46.28: was going to the market to buy a trousseau for his daughter. When the collectors of charity caught
46.29: sight of him they hid themselves from him. He ran after them and said to them: I adjure you, [tell
46.30: me] on what mission are you engaged? And they replied: [The marriage of] an orphaned pair. He
46.31: said to then: I swear, they must take precedence over my daughter. And he took all that he had and
46.32: gave to them. He was left with one zuz and with this he bought wheat which he deposited in the
46.33: granary. When his wife returned house she asked her daughter, What did your father bring home?
46.34: She replied, He has put in the granary all that he had bought. She thereupon went to open the door of
46.35: the granary and she found that it was so full of wheat that the wheat protruded through the hinges of
46.36: the door-socket and the door would not open on account of this. The daughter then went to the
46.37: Beth-Hamidrash and said to him [her father], Come and see what your Friend has done for you.
46.38: Whereupon he said to her, l swear,3 they shall be to you as devoted property, and you shall have no
46.39: more right to share in them than any poor person in Israel.4

46.55: Once Rabbi ordained a fast and no rain fell. Thereupon ‘Ilfa (some say, R. Ilfi),[stepped down
46.56: before the ark and] recited [the prayer], ‘He causeth the wind to blow’, and the wind blew. [He
46.57: continued], ‘He causeth the rain to fall’, and rain fell. Rabbi then asked him, What is your special
46.58: merit? He replied: I live in a poverty-stricken remote place where wine for Kiddush and Habdalah11
46.59: is unobtainable but I take the trouble to procure for myself wine for Kiddush and Habdalah and thus
46.60: help also others to fulfil their duty.
46.61: Once Rab came to a certain place and decreed a fast but no rain fell. The Reader then stepped
46.62: down at his request before the ark and recited, ‘He causeth the wind to blow’, and the wind blew; [he
46.63: continued], ‘He causeth the rain to fall’, and rain fell. Rab thereupon asked him, What is your special
46.64: merit? The latter replied: I am a teacher of young children and I teach the children of the poor as
46.65: well as those of the rich; I take no fees from any who cannot afford to pay; further, I have a fishpond
46.66: and any boy who is reluctant [to learn] I bribe with some of the fishes from it12 and thereby appease
46.67: him so that he becomes eager to learn.
46.68: Once R. Nahman ordained a fast and he prayed but no rain fell. He thereupon said, ‘Take Nahman
46.69: and throw him down from the wall to the ground’.13 He felt greatly dejected and then rain came .
